No. 79 Yingze West Street Taiyuan 030024 China A series of sulfonated activated carbon catalysts (AC-SO3H-x) were prepared by using sulfuric acid as the sulfating agent and used for the ethanolysis of furfuryl alcohol (FA) to ethyl levulinate (EL). The catalytic performance of AC-SO3H-x catalysts increased firstly and then decreased with introducing sulfuric acid and AC-SO3H-5 catalyst exhibited the highest activity with 95.3 % yield to EL and complete FA conversion, superior to that reported in the literature. Moreover, EL yield displayed the volcanic trend against with SO3H group concentration and the excellent catalytic performance of AC-SO3H-5 was attributed to appropriate surface acidity derived from the introduction of sulfonic acid groups (SO3H groups). Furthermore, it was firstly identified by the combination of FT-IR characterizations with Boehm's titration method that C-S bonds were formed through C atoms in phenolic hydroxyl groups of carbon surface bonding with SO3H groups. Additionally, the various sulfonation conditions and reaction conditions were optimized and it was found that low nFA/nEtOH (0.005) was very critical. This work provided a feasible strategy for the design of efficient carbon-based solid acid catalysts and innovatively elucidated the surface functional groups of carbon bonded to SO3H groups, which would drive the development of renewable FA to EL. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Furfuryl alcohol Ethyl levulinate Sulfonated activated carbon Ethanolysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the declining of nonrenewable resources such as oil and coal and the increasingly serious concern for the ecological environment, the synthesis of high value-added chemicals from regenerative biomass resources has attracted much attention in the past decades [1],2]. Lignocellulose biomass is abundant, economic and sustainable in nature, which make it a primary bioresource for the production of platform chemicals [3] including furfural (FFA) [4], furfuryl alcohol (FA) [5], 5-hydroxymethylfurfural [6], levulinic acid (LA) [7], ethyl levulinate (EL) [8], γ-valerolactone [9]. Among these chemicals, EL is one of the potential green biomass-based platform fine chemicals, containing a carbonyl group and an ester group, which endows it with special fragrance and can be used as spices and food flavorings [10]. Additionally, as a short chain fatty ester, EL can be also applied in multiple fields, such as solvent [11] and fuel additive [12]. More importantly, EL is considered to be a potential liquid biofuel in the future due to its advantages of high lubricity, stability of flash point, pour point, cloud point and boiling point. Currently, EL could be produced either through LA esterification or via the ethanolysis of FA, chloromethyl furfural (CMF) or biomass [13] (Scheme 1 ). However, the synthesis of EL from biomass had the problems of long reaction route and high cost in separation and purification, seriously hindering its industrialization [13]. In spite of short reaction pathway from either LA or CMF to EL, the production and separation of them were costly [14–16]. In contrast, FA has been recognized as a promising starting material for the production of EL, which not only can be obtained from inexpensive FFA easily, but also solved the problem of FFA oversupplied exceeding demand [17,18]. Acidic catalysts were vital for the ethanolysis of FA to EL [19–21], which were divided into homogeneous catalysts and heterogeneous ones. Homogeneous catalysts [22] containing hydrochloric acid, sulfuric acid, and benzenesulfonic acid, have been applied to the production of EL and exhibited high activity. Nevertheless, corrosion issues and pollution problems as well as difficulties in the separation and purification severely limited the applications of homogeneous catalysts. Comparatively, heterogeneous catalysts evolving zeolites [23,24], ion-exchange resins [25], metal salts [26], sulfated metal oxides [27], and organic–inorganic hybrid acids [28], have drawn more attention due to the characteristics of environmentally friendly and easy to separate. However, it was noted that the above catalysts were faced with such problems as the cumbersome process on the catalyst preparation, high costs or difficulty in regeneration. Consequently, the design of an economical and efficient heterogeneous catalyst has been the key point in the field of EL production through the ethanolysis of FA. Moreover, carbon materials have attracted widespread attention owing to their low prices, high specific surface area and corrosion resistance [29–31]. Currently, Chhabra et al. reported an activated charcoal loaded phosphomolybdic acid (PMAC) for ethanolysis of FA to EL and the yield was up to 63 % at 140 °C [32]. Guo et al. prepared a sulfonated functional carbon (S-FCM) by using 5-sulfosalicylic acid dihydrate as the sulfating agent and used for the FA ethanolysis reaction and found that S-FCM catalyst exhibited 69 % yield to EL due to the presence of SO3H groups [33]. Similarly, sulfonic acid functionalized coffee biochar (SFCB-x) exhibited increasing acid density and strength as x increased, attributing to the firm grafting of SO3H groups into the skeleton of SFCB-x catalysts [34]. The moderate catalytic activity of PMAC and S-FCM could be ascribed to the large surface area of carbon materials and the appropriate amount of Brønsted acid sites, while SFCB-4 had the highest SO3H density over a series of SFCB-x catalysts and thus exhibited higher yield of EL (81.7 %). However, several shortcomings of carbon-based solid acid catalysts including carbonization preparation process and relatively low activity should not be ignored, which was challenging to solve but critical for the design of efficient acidic catalysts. In the present work, a series of functioned activated carbon catalysts (AC-SO3H-x) were prepared using different amount of sulfuric acid as sulfonating agent and used for the ethanolysis of FA to EL. Specifically, influence of SO3H groups on the performance of activated carbon catalyst for ethanolysis of FA to EL will be deeply explored and the structure-performance of AC-SO3H-x catalysts were established based on various characterization results. Preparation factors (temperature and time in the sulfonating process) and reaction conditions including reaction temperature and the molar ratio of furfuryl alcohol to ethanol (nFA/nEtOH) were also investigated and the optimal catalytic performance with EL yield of 95.3 % was obtained over AC-SO3H-5 catalyst, exceeding other sulfonated activated carbon catalysts reported previously. Innovatively, it was clear that how to introduce SO3H groups firmly into the carbon carrier skeleton by the combination of FT-IR characterizations with Boehm's titration method, which was seldom reported and important for designing the extremely efficient solid carbon catalysts. This work would provide a highly efficient, simple and accessible catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials FA (98 %), ethanol (≥99.7 %), n-dodecane (≥99.5 %), EL (99 %), 2-Ethoxymethylfuran (2-EMF, 98 %) and activated carbon (AC) were directly purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. Concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98 %) was provided by Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd. Dichloromethane (99.5 %), ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4, 99 %), zirconium dioxide (ZrO2, ≤100 nm), phosphotungstic acid (H3PW12O40), acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene terpolymer (ABS resins), and graphene oxide (GO) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. HZSM-5 and HY were supplied by Tianjin Nankai Chemistry Catalysts Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The acidic activated carbon catalysts were prepared using different amount of H2SO4 as sulfonating agent by sulfonation method. Typically, 1 g of AC powder was successively added to water and a certain amount of concentrated sulfuric acid under vigorous stirring. Subsequently, the obtained solution was heated in water bath at 60 °C for 3 h and ultrasonic treatment for 1 h, followed by the centrifugation and washing with deionized water alternated with ethanol. Finally, the sulfonated activated carbon catalysts were obtained after drying at 60 °C overnight and denotated as AC-SO3H-x (x = 1, 5, 10), in which x represented the amount of H2SO4 added, mL. 2.3 Catalysts characterization The crystalline structure of the catalysts was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Ultima IV, Japan), using a Rigaku D/max 2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ range of 5–85° at a scanning rate of 4 °/min. The surface morphology was examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-4800, Japan). The specific surface area (SBET) and porous structure of the catalysts were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms on a Beishide 3H-2000PS2 analyzer at -196 °C. The thermal stability of catalysts was conducted by Thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) method on a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA Netzsch, Germany) in nitrogen atmosphere from 50 to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were recorded using an infrared spectrometer (Nicolet iS50, USA). The surface element composition and chemical state were determined using X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS, Escalab 250Xi, USA) and the binding energies were calibrated using the C 1 s binding energy of 284.8 eV. The acidities of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were quantified by pyridine adsorption FTIR spectra (Py-IR, Bruker tensor 27 spectrometer, Germany). The elemental content of AC and AC-SO3H-x catalysts was determined using a Vario EL III elemental analyzer, made by Elementar, Germany. The distribution of acidic groups over AC and AC-SO3H-x catalysts were determined by the Boehm's titration method [35,36]. The total acid site concentration of AC and AC-SO3H-x catalysts was obtained through acid-base titration method according to the equation as follows. Take AC-SO3H-5 for example, 0.1 g of AC-SO3H-5 was added to 20 mL of NaCl solution (2 mol/L) and the mixture was treated by stirring for 12 h and ultrasound for 5 h, after which the filtrate was titrated with 0.05 mol/L of NaOH solution using phenolphthalein as an indicator. Total acid site concentration ( mmol / g ) = c NaOH × V NaOH m × 1 0 3 where cNaOH was the concentration of NaOH solution (mol/L), VNaOH was the consumed volume of NaOH solution (L), and m was the dosage of AC and AC-SO3H-x catalyst (g). 2.4 Catalytic evaluation Various catalysts were evaluated for ethanolysis of FA in a 50 mL stainless-steel high-pressure reactor. In a typical experiment, 0.4 g of FA, 9.4 g of ethanol, and 0.1 g of catalyst were sequentially loaded into the reactor. Then the reactor was heated to 120 °C and maintained for 4 h under stirring at 900 rpm. After each run, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, then the products were analyzed using a GC-950 instrument (Wuhao Instrument Company) equipped with a capillary column (HPINNOWAX, Agilent). The catalytic activity can be described as the conversion of FA (CFA,%), the selectivity of EL (SEL,%), the selectivity of 2-EMF (S2-EMF,%), the yield of EL (YEL,%), wherein n-dodecane was used as the internal standard. The specific calculation formula was presented below: C FA ( % ) = n FA , 0 − n FA n FA , 0 × 100 % S EL ( % ) = n EL n FA , 0 − n FA × 100 % S 2 − EMF ( % ) = n 2 − EMF n FA , 0 − n FA × 100 % Y EL = C FA × S EL × 100 % Carbon balance ( % ) = n EL × 7 + n ethanol , 2 × 2 n ethanol , 1 × 2 + n FA × 5 × 100 % where nFA,0 was the initial moles of FA, nethanol,1 nethanol,2 were the initial moles of ethanol and the moles of remaining ethanol after reaction, nFA, nEL and n2-EMF were the moles of FA, EL and 2-EMF in the reaction product, respectively. For cycle evaluation process, the used catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and washed thoroughly with dichloromethane for three times to remove residual substances on the surface of the catalyst. The catalyst was later dried at 100 °C for 12 h for the next catalytic reaction. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization results 3.1.1 Textural and morphological properties The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the textural properties of AC-SO3H-x catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1 , respectively. For all the AC-SO3H-x catalysts, there was a steep increase of adsorption isotherms in the P/P0 range of 0-0.1, along with significant hysteresis loops in the range of 0.4–0.9, demonstrating the coexistence of microporous and mesoporous structure according to the IUPAC classification. Compared with AC catalyst, a slight decrease in nitrogen adsorption capacities was observed over AC-SO3H-x catalysts, which was consistent with the decline of the surface area and average pore size as shown in Table 2 . Moreover, the specific surface area was 1423.5, 1339.9, 1190.7 and 1077.6 m2 g-1 for AC, AC-SO3H-1, AC-SO3H-5 and AC-SO3H-10, respectively, indicating that the introduction of H2SO4 would cause the decreasing of specific surface area, which was consistent with the results of literature [37]. In addition, it was also found that both micropore volume and mesoporous volume in the AC-SO3H-x catalysts decreased with the increase of x, which might be interpreted by the blocking of the pores partially and the destruction of some thin pore walls in the AC derived from the gradual introduction of SO3H groups [38–40]. XRD patterns of AC and AC-SO3H-x catalysts are displayed in Fig. 2 . Obviously, there were three obvious diffraction peaks at 22.9°, 26.5° and 43.3° for AC and AC-SO3H-x catalysts, which were corresponded to the amorphous carbon, (002) plane and (101) plane of graphitic carbon, respectively [37,41]. Notably, the narrower and sharper (002) peak for the AC-SO3H-x catalysts indicated that the graphitization degree in amorphous carbon was enhanced as the introduction of SO3H groups, while the weak diffraction peak of graphitized carbon at 43.3° manifested that AC had a good structural stability [42]. Moreover, the breadth and intensity of diffraction peak at 26.5° was enhanced in AC-SO3H-x catalysts with the increasing x compared with AC catalyst, implying that the introduced SO3H groups could transform ordered carbon into disordered graphite structure, which was in good accordance with the literature [34]. Remarkably, the growing trend of relative intensity of the (002) peak from AC-SO3H-1 to AC-SO3H-10 was observed, which should be caused by the drop of micropore volume in the sulfonated catalysts as Shiryaev reported [43]. SEM images of AC and AC-SO3H-x catalysts were shown in Fig. 3 . Seen from the Fig. 3, there was no significant difference in the morphology over AC-SO3H-x catalysts and a large number of cracks were observed on the outer surface of them, which could provide more reaction sites and thus facilitate the introduction of SO3H groups to the inner and outer surfaces of AC [44]. The TGA curves of the AC and AC-SO3H-5 are given in Fig. 4 . AC exhibited a slow decrease in weight of about 17 % up to 700 °C, revealing that the structure of AC was excellently stable. However, the DTG curve of AC-SO3H-5 presented three weight loss processes. Specifically, the first one below 150 °C could be attributed to the loss of water, while the second weight loss (around 30.5 %) in the range of 150–350 °C could be assigned to the removal of the SO3H groups and other oxygen-containing groups, indicating that SO3H groups were successfully introduced to the AC. Additionally, a sharp exothermic peak at 120 °C was observed in the DTG curve of AC-SO3H-5 due to the partial degradation of SO3H groups. The third weight loss (350∼700 °C) could be attributed to the graphitization of carbon materials [34]. According to the TGA result, it was inferred that the AC-SO3H-5 catalyst had relatively good stability at the reaction temperature below 120 °C, though the functional groups in AC-SO3H-5 can be destroyed at high temperature. 3.1.2 Surface acidity The FT-IR spectra of AC-SO3H-x catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . The FT-IR absorption peaks at around 3200, 2921, 1694, and 1563 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching vibration of O-H, C-H, C=O and C=C bonds, respectively [33,45]. For AC-SO3H-x catalysts, the peaks at around 1183 and 1035 cm−1 observed were corresponding to the symmetric stretching vibration of O=S=O bonds and the asymmetric stretching vibration of –SO3 2− groups in the sulfonic acid groups, respectively [46,47]. Besides, the absorption peak at around 580 cm−1 attributed to the stretching vibration of C–S bonds was also present in AC-SO3H-x catalysts, while it was absent in AC catalyst. Interestingly, the adsorption peaks due to both the C–S bonds and SO3H groups became gradually stronger with the increase of x, demonstrating that not only SO3H groups have been successfully incorporated into AC after the sulfonation process, but also the enlargement of H2SO4 amount facilitated the enhancement in the concentration of surface SO3H groups [34,48]. The element composition of the AC and AC-SO3H-5 catalysts was analyzed by XPS, as shown in Fig. 6 . The survey spectra of AC and AC-SO3H-5 was shown in Fig. S2, which confirmed the presence of carbon and oxygen in AC and the existence of C, O and S in AC-SO3H-5. It could be found that peaks at 288.5 eV in Fig. 6a, 533.2 eV in Fig. 6b, 168.9 and 170.3 eV in Fig. 6c were corresponded to COOH, C−OH and SO3H groups, respectively, indicating that SO3H groups and hydroxyl groups coexisted in the AC-SO3H-5 catalyst [49]. Seen from the XPS spectra of C 1 s excitation (Fig. 6a), three peaks at 284.8, 286.3, and 288.5 eV were observed in AC and AC-SO3H-5 catalyst, corresponding to C=C bonds, C=O bonds, and COOH groups respectively. The O 1s peak was deconvoluted to two components at about 531.6 and 533.2 eV corresponding to C=O bonds and C-OH bonds, respectively. Notably, compared with AC, the variation of peak intensity at 531.6 eV in AC-SO3H-5 displayed in Fig. 6b, was attributed to the enhancement of carboxyl groups, lactone groups and carbonyl groups. As shown in Fig. 6c, the S 2p peaks could only be observed in the AC-SO3H-5 catalyst, demonstrating the successful introduction of S atoms into the AC. Specifically, the S 2p XPS spectrum of AC-SO3H-5 could be deconvoluted into three peaks: C-S bond (165.5 eV), –SO x bond (168.9 eV) and S–O bond (170.3 eV), respectively [34,49,50]. Moreover, the percentages of O and S increased from 12.60 % to 14.11 % and from 0.31 % to 1.24 % after the sulfonation process respectively, which further ascertained that SO3H groups were successfully incorporated into the AC-SO3H-5 catalyst, which was consistent with FT-IR results. For a further investigation of surface acidity of catalyst, the Py-IR analysis was conducted over AC and AC-SO3H-x catalysts and the results were shown in Fig. S3. Obviously, there were three main infrared adsorption bands at 1540, 1490, and 1450 cm−1. Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites were responsible for the adsorption bands at 1540 and 1450 cm−1, respectively, while pyridine adsorption at both Brønsted acid and Lewis acid sites accounted for the band at about 1490 cm−1 [30,51]. The Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites were calculated based on the corresponding peak area at 150, 300 and 450 °C [52], which were listed in Table S1. As shown in Fig. S3, the density of Brønsted acid sites increased with the increase of x, while there was no obvious trend for Lewis acid sites, which indicated that Brønsted acid sites was the dominant contributor to the acidity of AC-SO3H-x catalysts. The Brønsted acidic sites might be derived from the S-O groups on the catalyst surface [30], while the Lewis acidic sites might be derived from the S-C bonds and dehydration of Brønsted acid sites [53,54]. Furthermore, the degradation of SO3H groups above 150 °C accounted for the decline of total peak areas, suggesting that AC-SO3H-x were thermally unstable at higher adsorption temperature. Consequently, NH3-TPD characterization was not allowed for AC-SO3H-x catalysts to obtain the corresponding acidity amount. In conclusion, the moderate Brønsted acid sites provided middle acid strength, which facilitated the ethanolysis of FA to EL. 3.1.3 Surface functional groups The content of carbon and sulfur in AC and AC-SO3H-x catalysts were measured by elemental analysis and listed in Table 3 . Evidently, the sulfur content mounted from 0.06 to 3.31wt% with the increasing introduced H2SO4 for sulfonated catalysts, confirming the incorporation of SO3H groups into AC via sulfonation process. All sulfur in sulfonated carbon material was confined to SO3H groups based on the XPS analysis, hence, the concentration of SO3H groups could be calculated via the sulfur content obtained by elemental analysis [46,55]. As was displayed in Table 3, the total acid site concentration grew linearly with increasing x, and the proportion of SO3H group concentration in total acid site concentration rose in AC-SO3H-1 (9.49 %), AC-SO3H-5 (15.8 %) and AC-SO3H-10 catalysts (19.25 %), which was markedly higher than that in AC catalyst (0.75 %). In order to further explore the acidity of AC-SO3H-x catalysts, the quantitative analysis of acidic functional groups was performed by Boehm's titration and the results were summarized in Table S2. As displayed in Table S2, the concentration of carboxyl groups, lactone groups and carbonyl groups were increasing with x, while the concentration of phenolic hydroxyl groups appeared the declining trend. This phenomenon not only demonstrated that the SO3H groups primarily bonded to the C atoms in phenolic hydroxyl groups, but also well accounted for the shift of peak at 531.6 eV in Fig. 6b. It can be concluded that the moderate acid site concentration of AC-SO3H-5 was also associated with the middle concentration of SO3H groups. In addition, the total acid site concentration was 4.05 mmol/g, and was equivalent to the concentration of SO3H groups (3.77 mmol/g) obtained by TGA analysis, indicating that most of the acidic sites were accessible on the surface of the AC-SO3H-5 catalyst. It can be also concluded that the second weight loss in TGA analysis was exactly resulted from the removal of the SO3H groups and other oxygen-containing groups, which was in agreement with the literature [34]. 3.2 Catalytic results The catalytic performance of FA ethanolysis to EL over AC and AC-SO3H-x catalysts were summarized in Table 1. Apparently, FA conversion of only 0.2 % was obtained without any products detected by GC in the blank experiment, pointing that almost no reaction of FA ethanolysis occurred in the absence of the catalyst. Nevertheless, the carbon balance was only 87.1 %, most possibly resulting from the occurrence of ethanol dehydration reaction to form undetectable diethyl ether instead of FA ethanolysis reaction. AC displayed FA conversion of 1.2 % and 2-EMF selectivity of 3.6 %, but EL was still not produced. The phenomenon could be reasonably interpreted by the fact that the surface acidity originating from the –COOH and –OH groups on the carbon material was not enough to promote 2-EMF ring-opening to further generate EL [33]. Surprisingly, the activity of catalysts exhibited a significant improvement after sulfonation treatment with a certain amount of H2SO4 solution under the same reaction conditions. The conversion of FA was up to 100 % over AC-SO3H-x, while the EL yield first increased and then decreased and the maximum of 95.3 % in AC-SO3H-5, indicating that AC with appropriate H2SO4 amount was beneficial to FA ethanolysis to EL. The EL yield of AC-SO3H-10 decreased to 82.6 % without 2-EMF produced, which can be speculated that excessive H2SO4 caused the polymerization of FA and the formation of diethyl ether. For comparison, a series of solid acid catalysts, including AC-SO3H-5, HY, HZSM-5, GO, H3PW12O40/ZrO2, SO4 2−/ZrO2, and ABS resins, were evaluated for FA ethanolysis to EL under the same reaction conditions, as summarized in Fig. S1. It was seen from Fig. S1 that the investigated solid acid catalysts exhibited very different activity and FA conversion was in the order of AC-SO3H-5 > HZSM-5 > ABS resins > SO4 2−/ZrO2 >GO > HY > H3PW12O40/ZrO2. Due to variation in FA conversion, the above catalysts presented different tendency of EL yield as follows: AC-SO3H-5 (95.3 %) > ABS resins (65.3 %)> SO4 2−/ZrO2 (62.6 %) > HZSM-5 (61 %) > GO (38.6 %) > H3PW12O40/ZrO2 (24.2 %) > HY (12.7 %). The result manifested that the structure of the acid catalyst seriously affected the degree of FA ethanolysis and AC-SO3H-5 possessed the significant superiority. 3.2.1 Effect of the sulfonation temperature and sulfonation time Sulfonation process was very vital for enhancement in the catalytic performance of AC in the synthesis of EL from FA. The influence of the sulfonation temperature and sulfonation time on the activity of AC-SO3H-5 for FA ethanolysis were investigated and displayed in Fig. 7 a and Fig. 7b, respectively. With the increasing of sulfonation temperature, all the AC-SO3H-5 catalysts exhibited FA conversion of 100 %, while EL yield rose from 62.2 % to 83.8 % when sulfonation temperature ranging from 40 °C to 60 °C and then dropped to 43.3 % at 100 °C, reaching the peak at the sulfonation temperature of 60 °C. It was assumed that the low sulfonation temperature was not enough to activate the surface functional groups to form C–S bonds and SO3H groups, while the high sulfonation temperature would result in the collapse of mesopores structure in AC. In addition, AC-SO3H-5 catalyst treated with different sulfonation time also showed 100 % FA conversion, but volcanic curve of the EL yield or selectivity with the gradual increase of sulfonation time from 1 to 7 h was obtained. When the sulfonation time was 3 h, AC-SO3H-5 displayed the highest EL yield of 83.8 %. In contrast, the sulfonation time of AC-SO3H-5 was 1 h, 5 h and 7 h exhibited similar activity about 79 % in FA ethanolysis reaction, that is, extending time to 7 h or shorting time to 1 h would result in the decline of EL yield, though that decrease was not statistically significant. This phenomenon could be explained that the shorter sulfonation time was unable to totally introduce SO3H groups into the skeleton of AC, while the continued extension of sulfonation time from 3 h to 7 h did not cause significant changes in the surface functional groups of AC-SO3H-5 catalyst. Therefore, the optimal sulfonation temperature was 60 °C and sulfonation time was 3 h, which was applied to prepare the catalyst used for further optimizing the reaction conditions. 3.2.2 Effect of the reaction temperature, reaction time and nFA/nEtOH The influence of the reaction conditions involved reaction temperature, reaction time and nFA/nEtOH on EL yield of AC-SO3H-5 was investigated and the results were shown in Fig. 8 . As shown in Fig. 8a, FA conversion could keep 100 %, while an obvious increase of EL yield was observed with increasing reaction temperature from 100 to 120 °C and the decline from 83.8 % to 73.2 % was present as further the temperature increases to 140 °C, which was possibly due to the production of intermediate including 2-EMF [19,30,56]. However, it was clear that 2-EMF selectivity also gradually decreased, so we speculated that 4, 5-diethoxy-5-hydroxypentan-2-one (DHP) or 4, 5, 5-triethoxypentan-2-one (TEP) produced as the main intermediate despite they were beyond our detection, which was consistent with the conclusion in the report [18,23]. This founding demonstrated that reaction temperature had an important effect on the catalytic performance and even reaction path. Additionally, the impact of reaction time on the catalytic performance of FA ethanolysis was explored and the volcano curve was obtained (Fig. 8b). With the progress of reaction time from 1 h to 4 h, EL yield rapidly increased from 69.3 % to 83.8 %, while 2-EMF selectivity grew from 0 % to 4.2 % and then declined to 0.8 %. However, the EL yield and 2-EMF selectivity decreased as the time further increased to 6 h, indicating that EL might decompose and undesirable byproducts were formed under higher temperature and longer time [29,57]. Based on the above results, the reaction temperature and reaction time was optimized and was set 120 °C and 4 h. Fig. 8c showed the effect of nFA/nEtOH on the catalytis performance of AC-SO3H-5 catalyst during the reaction of FA ethanolysis to EL. Obviously, EL yield decreased gradually with the increasing of nFA/nEtOH, implying that the decreasing of nFA/nEtOH facilitated the EL generation from FA ethanolysis. Surprisingly, when the nFA/nEtOH was as low as 0.005, the yield of EL was as high as 95.3 %, which was dramatically superior to that in the report as shown in Table 4 . The satisfactory result displayed that a smaller amount of FA effectively reduced the polymerization and enhanced the selectivity and yield of EL [19,58]. Besides, even if the dosage of catalyst was minimized by half, the yield of EL decreased by only 1.9 % (Fig. S4). Through the analysis of Fig. 8c, when nFA/nEtOH was ranging from 0.005 to 0.1, it was noticed that the EL yield decreased from 95.3 % to 52.3 % and 2-EMF was almost inexistent, along with a slight decrease of the carbon balance (89.3 %). It could be inferred that FA was converted to EL through forming the undetected intermediates DHP or TEP, and partial FA was more likely to polymerize at high concentration in acidic environment [58,59]. Furthermore, the AC-SO3H-5 catalyst was compared with other carbon-based solid acid catalysts recently reported for the synthesis of EL from FA ethanolysis. As was listed in Table 4, most of the carbon-based solid acid catalysts used for the production of EL were sulfonated carbon materials. The GO [60], PMAC [32], GCC [29], S-FCM [33] and S-AC [33] catalyst had the relatively low EL yield of 62.9 %, 63 %, 67.1 %, 69 % and 68 %, respectively. It should be noted that P-C-800 [30], SFCB-4 [34], and ArSO3H -HMCSs [37] catalyst presented the higher activity than all catalysts above mentioned. However, most of the catalysts reported in the literature adopted complex preparation process or exhibited low catalytic performance in the conversion of FA into EL, which was difficult to achieve large-scale production in practical applications. In contrast, the AC-SO3H-5 catalyst was a feasible and efficient catalyst for the synthesis of EL, which gave 100 % FA conversion and 95.3 % EL yield. 3.2.3 Reusability of AC-SO3H-5 The stability of AC-SO3H-5 was investigated under the optimized condition and the result were displayed in Fig. 9 . As can be seen from Fig. 9, the recovered AC-SO3H-5 washed with dichloromethane maintained excellent catalytic stability at 120 °C for the ethanolysis of FA to EL. Especially, AC-SO3H-5 could maintain complete conversion of FA in the first three cycles and possessed the EL selectivity of 85.3 %. Until the fifth cycle, the conversion of FA decreased from 100 % to 87.8 %, while the selectivity of EL reduced from 95.3 % to 65.7 %. It could be attributed to the weight loss of catalyst, slight leaching of SO3H groups in dichloromethane and the formation of insoluble humins on the active sites of the surface of AC-SO3H-5 catalyst in the recycle process [61–63]. In a word, AC-SO3H-5 catalyst had high stability in addition to the excellent catalytic activity, which was essential for the establishment of a sustainable and economically feasible catalytic system in the practical application. 3.3 Discussions 3.3.1 Structure–activity relationship The AC-SO3H-x catalysts with different x (x = 1, 5, 10) synthesized via sulfonation method demonstrated significantly superior catalytic activity than AC in the ethanolysis of FA to EL. Specifically, AC-SO3H-5 exhibited the full FA conversion and the maximum EL yield of 95.3 %, remarkably higher than other heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literature. To clarify the structure–activity relationship, the EL yield was plotted against as a function of SO3H group concentration (mmol/g) for AC-SO3H-x catalysts as shown in Fig. 10 a. The EL yield displayed volcanic trend with increasing x and peaked at the SO3H group concentration of 0.64 mmol/g. AC and AC-SO3H-1 exhibited the lower EL yield about 0 and 39.3 %, respectively, indicating sufficient SO3H groups were required to catalyze FA to produce EL. However, when the SO3H group concentration was higher than 0.64 mmol/g, the decreased EL yield of AC-SO3H-10 was possibly caused by polymerization of FA in excessive acidic environment [19,58,59]. Furthermore, it was notable that total acid site concentration positively correlated with SO3H group concentration in AC-SO3H-x catalysts, as shown in Fig. 10b. It was reasonably deemed that SO3H groups with moderate amount were critical to conversion of FA to EL [13,56], which was possibly due to the reduction of the polymerization of FA even at a high nFA/nEtOH. Acidity played an essential part in the ethanolysis of FA to EL. However, AC exhibited the FA conversion of only 1.2 % without EL produced even if possessing acidic functional groups including carboxyl groups, lactone groups, phenolic hydroxyl groups and carbonyl groups, demonstrating that the surface acidity was too weak to generate EL. By contrast, the acid strength of SO3H groups was sufficient to promote the production of EL from FA. Unfortunately, it was difficult to characterize the acid strength of AC-SO3H-x, but it was certain that acid strength of SO3H groups was stronger than other acidic functional groups in the surface of AC [33]. Innovatively, we inferred that the SO3H groups was covalently attached to C atoms originated from phenolic hydroxyl groups to further form C-S bonds based on Boehm's titration results (Table S2), which was in concordance with FT-IR and XPS results. 3.3.2 Proposed mechanism for FA ethanolysis Based upon the identified reaction product in this work and that of previously reported in the literature, the possible intermediates and reaction mechanism on the ethanolysis of FA to EL over AC-SO3H-x catalysts were proposed (Scheme 2 ). This mechanism might involve 2-EMF route and DHP and TEP multi-paths, which synergistically promoted the production of EL [59]. The ethanolysis of FA to EL underwent ring-opening due to the instability of the furan ring, which was similar to alcoholysis of FA to methyl levulinate [64]. On the one hand, the oxygen atom of furan ring in FA molecules was protonated by the SO3H sites to form species A, then species A was attacked by ethanol molecules to form 2-EMF and water. Afterwards, 2-EMF reacted with water under acidic conditions and underwent ring-opening to form species B, ultimately isomerizing to produce EL. The deduction accounted for the results that the selectivity of 2-EMF grew from 0 % to 0.8 % and then declined to none with the increase of nFA/nEtOH from 0.005 to 0.1, indicative of the presence of 2-EMF as the intermediate and the slower transformation of species B to EL. On the other hand, the hydroxyl group of FA was protonated to produce species C by the SO3H sites firstly, then species D and E were formed through ring-opening reaction under the attack of ethanol. Subsequently, species D and E were deprotonated to attain intermediate DHP and TEP respectively, eventually isomerizing to form EL. Besides, TEP could be also obtained when DHP was attacked by ethanol in the presence of water molecules [64]. Regrettably, it was seldom possible to calibrate DHP and TEP, thus the selectivity of DHP and TEP was inaccessible. Notably, it was deduced that undetected DHP and TEP were produced as the intermediates based on the combination of the carbon balance in the range of 83.3 %–94.7 % with total selectivity in the range of 63.6 %–95.3 % over AC-SO3H-x catalysts, which was coherent with the literature [64]. In addition, the formation of diethyl ether was attributed to the production of EL from TEP and the intermolecular dehydration reaction with ethanol [18,23]. According to the literature [13,27], the isomerization of the intermediates (2-EMF, DHP, TEP) was proved to be endothermic and far slower than the FA transformation into these intermediates, thus was deemed as a decisive procedure [56]. In conclusion, two reaction paths coexisted and path 1 was a main route to produce EL over the AC-SO3H-x catalysts, which was consistent with the literature [54,65]. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of acidic activated carbon catalysts (AC-SO3H-x) with large surface area (>1000 m2 .g-1) were successfully synthesized through controlling the introduced H2SO4 amount via sulfonation method for ethanolysis of FA to EL. Compared with AC, AC-SO3H-x exhibited significantly more efficient catalytic performance owing to introduction of SO3H groups into the skeleton of AC. With the H2SO4 amount (x) increasing, EL yield increased firstly and then decreased and AC-SO3H-5 catalyst possessed the highest activity attributing to the appropriate surface acidity. Moreover, the volcanic trend of EL yield against with SO3H group concentration and the linear relationship between total acid site concentration and SO3H group concentration were observed. AC-SO3H-5 with moderate SO3H group concentration showed the most excellent EL yield of 95.3 % with complete FA conversion, superior to that reported in the literature, which was obtained at the optimal reaction condition of 120 °C in 4 h and a low nFA/nEtOH of 0.005. Most innovatively, it was firstly identified by the combination of FT-IR characterizations with Boehm's titration method that C-S bonds were formed through C atoms in phenolic hydroxyl groups of carbon surface bonding with SO3H groups. This research provided the theoretical and experimental basis for designing feasible and available sulfonated carbon catalyst, which was urgently demanding for efficient conversion of FA to EL. coredata.dc:description: A series of sulfonated activated carbon catalysts (AC-SO3H-x) were prepared by using sulfuric acid as the sulfating agent and used for the ethanolysis of furfuryl alcohol (FA) to ethyl levulinate (EL). The catalytic performance of AC-SO3H-x catalysts increased firstly and then decreased with introducing sulfuric acid and AC-SO3H-5 catalyst exhibited the highest activity with 95.3 % yield to EL and complete FA conversion, superior to that reported in the literature. Moreover, EL yield displayed the volcanic trend against with SO3H group concentration and the excellent catalytic performance of AC-SO3H-5 was attributed to appropriate surface acidity derived from the introduction of sulfonic acid groups (SO3H groups). Furthermore, it was firstly identified by the combination of FT-IR characterizations with Boehm's titration method that C-S bonds were formed through C atoms in phenolic hydroxyl groups of carbon surface bonding with SO3H groups. Additionally, the various sulfonation conditions and reaction conditions were optimized and it was found that low nFA/nEtOH (0.005) was very critical. This work provided a feasible strategy for the design of efficient carbon-based solid acid catalysts and innovatively elucidated the surface functional groups of carbon bonded to SO3H groups, which would drive the development of renewable FA to EL.
